batch.title: Campbell Biology Ch 31 — Fungi (Olympiad)
batch.subject: Biology
batch.description: Olympiad-grade questions on fungal biology from Campbell Biology Chapter 31. Covers fungal nutrition, diversity, reproduction, ecological roles, mycorrhizal symbioses, lichens, pathogenesis, decomposition, and biotechnology applications.

questions.question: Mycorrhizal helper bacteria (MHB) are soil bacteria that:
options: compete with mycorrhizal fungi for root colonization sites
facilitate mycorrhizal establishment by stimulating fungal spore germination, hyphal growth, and root colonization
destroy mycorrhizal fungi through antibiotic production
are pathogenic bacteria that weaken plants, making them more susceptible to fungal colonization
questions.explanation: Mycorrhizal helper bacteria (MHB) are soil bacteria that positively influence the establishment and functioning of mycorrhizal symbioses. MHB facilitate mycorrhization through several mechanisms: (1) production of volatile compounds and metabolites that stimulate fungal spore germination and hyphal branching, (2) modification of the root surface to enhance fungal attachment, (3) production of plant hormones that promote root growth and branching (creating more potential colonization sites), (4) detoxification of inhibitory soil compounds, and (5) nutrient mobilization that benefits both the fungus and plant. Well-characterized MHB include species of Pseudomonas, Bacillus, and Burkholderia. The tripartite interaction among plant, mycorrhizal fungus, and MHB represents a complex mutualistic network where bacterial facilitation enhances the efficiency of the plant-fungal symbiosis.

questions.question: An experiment measures plant growth with different mycorrhizal treatments in phosphorus-poor soil: No mycorrhizae — biomass 2.1 g; AM fungi — biomass 8.4 g; ECM fungi — biomass 7.2 g; AM + phosphorus supplement — biomass 8.8 g; No mycorrhizae + phosphorus supplement — biomass 7.9 g. What conclusion is best supported?
options: Mycorrhizae primarily enhance growth by improving phosphorus uptake, as phosphorus supplementation nearly equalizes growth without mycorrhizae
Mycorrhizae provide benefits that cannot be replicated by phosphorus addition
Ectomycorrhizal fungi are always inferior to arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi
Phosphorus supplementation completely eliminates the need for mycorrhizal associations
questions.explanation: The data shows that both AM and ECM fungi dramatically enhance plant growth in phosphorus-poor soil (2.1 g to 8.4/7.2 g, a 3-4x increase). Critically, phosphorus supplementation without mycorrhizae (7.9 g) nearly matches the mycorrhizal treatments (8.4/7.2 g), strongly suggesting that the primary benefit of mycorrhizal fungi is enhanced phosphorus uptake rather than other mechanisms. The AM + phosphorus treatment (8.8 g) shows only a marginal additional benefit over AM alone (8.4 g), indicating that mycorrhizae and phosphorus supplementation are largely substitutable. However, 'nearly' is key—the small differences (8.4 vs 7.9 g) suggest mycorrhizae may provide minor additional benefits beyond phosphorus uptake, such as improved water relations, enhanced nitrogen uptake, or disease protection. This experiment demonstrates why mycorrhizal associations are especially important in phosphorus-limited environments.

questions.question: The yeast-to-hypha transition in dimorphic fungi such as Histoplasma capsulatum is triggered primarily by:
options: temperature shift from environmental (25 degrees C, mold form) to host body temperature (37 degrees C, yeast form)
changes in ambient light intensity
contact with specific host cell surface receptors
availability of atmospheric oxygen versus carbon dioxide
questions.explanation: Dimorphic fungi exhibit temperature-dependent morphological switching that is central to their pathogenicity. At environmental temperatures (~25 degrees C), Histoplasma capsulatum grows as a saprophytic mold (mycelial form) in soil enriched with bird or bat droppings. When inhaled into the lungs, the shift to body temperature (37 degrees C) triggers conversion to the pathogenic yeast form. This transition involves dramatic reprogramming of gene expression: the yeast form expresses virulence factors including cell wall alpha-(1,3)-glucan (which prevents immune recognition), calcium-binding protein CBP1, and superoxide dismutase (which neutralizes host reactive oxygen species). Similar temperature-dependent dimorphism occurs in other systemic pathogens: Blastomyces, Coccidioides, Paracoccidioides, and Talaromyces. The molecular mechanisms involve heat shock proteins, signaling cascades, and transcription factors that sense and respond to the temperature shift.

questions.question: The phenomenon of 'fairy rings' in lawns is caused by:
options: a circular colony of bioluminescent bacteria
chemical contamination of the soil in a ring pattern
wind patterns depositing mushroom spores in a circular arrangement
the outward radial growth of a basidiomycete mycelium, with mushrooms appearing at the actively growing periphery
questions.explanation: Fairy rings are caused by the centrifugal growth of a basidiomycete mycelium through soil. A fungal colony typically begins from a single spore or hyphal fragment and grows outward in all directions at a relatively constant rate. As the central portion of the mycelium ages and depletes local nutrients, it dies, leaving an expanding ring of active growth at the periphery. Mushrooms (basidiocarps) appear at this actively growing front, forming the visible ring. The soil chemistry at the ring margin is altered by fungal activity: enzyme secretion releases nitrogen from organic matter, often producing a ring of lush, dark green grass just ahead of the mushroom zone. Some fairy rings are ancient—growth rates of 10-30 cm per year mean that large rings (over 10 meters in diameter) may be decades old, and some rings in European grasslands are estimated to be over 700 years old.

questions.question:
About lichen biology:
(I) The fungal partner (mycobiont) provides structure and protection while the photobiont provides carbohydrates
(II) Lichens can colonize bare rock surfaces and contribute to soil formation through chemical weathering
(III) Lichens grow rapidly, averaging 10 cm per year in most environments
(IV) Lichens are sensitive to air pollution, particularly sulfur dioxide, making them useful bioindicators
Which are TRUE?
options: TTFT — I, II, and IV are true
TFTF — I and III are true
TTTF — I, II, and III are true
TFFT — I and IV are true
questions.explanation: Statement I is TRUE: In the lichen symbiosis, the mycobiont (usually an ascomycete) forms the structural framework of the thallus, protecting the photobiont from desiccation and UV radiation. The photobiont (green alga or cyanobacterium) provides photosynthetically produced carbohydrates. Statement II is TRUE: Lichens are pioneer colonizers of bare rock surfaces. They produce organic acids (particularly oxalic acid and carbonic acid) that chemically weather rock, and their physical penetration (rhizine attachment) mechanically fractures surfaces. Over time, this creates mineral particles that mix with dead lichen organic matter to form primitive soil. Statement III is FALSE: Lichens are extremely slow-growing organisms, typically growing only 0.1-10 mm per year depending on species and conditions. Some crustose lichens in extreme environments grow less than 0.1 mm per year. Statement IV is TRUE: Many lichen species are highly sensitive to air pollutants, particularly SO2, making lichen community composition a reliable bioindicator of air quality.

questions.question: Fungi are classified as heterotrophs that obtain nutrition by:
options: ingesting food particles through a mouth-like structure
photosynthesizing using chloroplasts acquired through endosymbiosis
absorbing nutrients from the environment after secreting extracellular enzymes
fixing atmospheric nitrogen using nitrogenase enzymes
questions.explanation: Fungi are absorptive heterotrophs—they obtain carbon and energy from organic molecules in their environment. Unlike animals, which ingest food and digest it internally, fungi secrete a battery of hydrolytic enzymes (cellulases, proteases, lipases, amylases, lignin peroxidases) into their surroundings, breaking down complex organic molecules extracellularly. The resulting small molecules (sugars, amino acids, fatty acids) are then absorbed through the fungal cell membrane. This absorptive nutrition strategy is facilitated by the enormous surface-area-to-volume ratio of the hyphal growth form. Hyphae penetrate substrates and secrete enzymes at their tips, creating a highly efficient nutrient extraction system. Fungi can decompose virtually all organic materials, including cellulose, lignin, chitin, and keratin, making them the primary decomposers in most terrestrial ecosystems.

questions.question: The Hartig net in ectomycorrhizal associations is:
options: a network of bacterial biofilms surrounding root hairs
a lattice of fungal hyphae that grows between root cortical cells, providing the interface for nutrient exchange
a mesh of root hairs that captures fungal spores from the soil
a protective net of spider silk around vulnerable root tips
questions.explanation: The Hartig net is the defining anatomical feature of ectomycorrhizal (ECM) associations. It consists of fungal hyphae that penetrate between the epidermal and cortical cells of the root, creating a labyrinthine interface between fungal and plant cell surfaces. The Hartig net dramatically increases the contact area between the two symbionts, facilitating bidirectional nutrient exchange: phosphorus and nitrogen move from fungus to plant, while photosynthetic carbon (sugars) moves from plant to fungus. The Hartig net hyphae do not penetrate plant cell walls—exchange occurs across the apoplastic interface. In angiosperms, the Hartig net is typically restricted to the epidermal cell layer, while in gymnosperms it may extend one or two cells deeper into the cortex. The ECM mantle and extramatrical mycelium extend from the Hartig net outward, exploring the soil for nutrients.

questions.question: Fungal prions, discovered in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, are significant because they demonstrate that:
options: all fungi are pathogenic to animals through prion transmission
protein-based inheritance (non-Mendelian) can occur in eukaryotes, with self-propagating protein conformations acting as heritable elements
DNA is not required for any form of genetic inheritance
fungal prions cause spongiform encephalopathies identical to mad cow disease
questions.explanation: Fungal prions, particularly [PSI+] and [URE3] in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, were among the first prion-like elements discovered outside of mammals. These are self-propagating protein conformations that act as heritable genetic elements independent of DNA sequence changes. The [PSI+] prion is an altered conformation of the translation termination factor Sup35, which when in its prion form causes read-through of stop codons, effectively altering the proteome. [PSI+] is inherited through cytoplasmic transmission and can be 'cured' by certain treatments. Yeast prions have provided crucial insights into protein misfolding diseases and demonstrated that protein-based inheritance is a broader biological phenomenon than initially recognized. Some researchers propose that yeast prions may function as adaptive mechanisms, creating phenotypic diversity in clonal populations that could be beneficial in fluctuating environments—a form of 'bet-hedging' at the molecular level.

questions.question: Lichens represent a mutualistic symbiosis between fungi and photosynthetic partners. Recent research has challenged the traditional view of lichens as two-partner symbioses. What was the surprising discovery?
options: Lichens are not actually symbioses at all

Many lichens harbor a third symbiotic partner—basidiomycete yeasts embedded in the cortex—in addition to the ascomycete mycobiont and photobiont, and the lichen microbiome includes diverse bacterial communities that contribute to nutrient cycling, protection, and secondary metabolite production
The photosynthetic partner is always a flowering plant
Fungi in lichens are always parasites of the algae
questions.explanation: Lichen biology is more complex than traditionally understood: (1) Classic model: Two-partner symbiosis—mycobiont (usually ascomycete, rarely basidiomycete) + photobiont (green algae like Trebouxia, or cyanobacteria like Nostoc, or both in tripartite lichens). (2) Third partner: Spribille et al. (2016) discovered that many lichens contain basidiomycete yeasts (Cyphobasidiales) in the cortex, correlating with phenotypic differences between lichen species. (3) Lichen microbiome: Diverse bacterial communities (Alphaproteobacteria, Actinobacteria) are consistently associated with lichens. These bacteria may contribute to: nitrogen fixation (in cyanolichens), phosphate solubilization, production of vitamins and hormones, and protection against pathogens through antibiotic production. (4) Nature of the relationship: The mycobiont-photobiont relationship ranges from mutualism to controlled parasitism. Some mycobionts parasitize photobionts (haustoria penetrating algal cells). (5) Ecological significance: Lichens colonize ~8% of terrestrial surfaces, fix significant nitrogen in boreal forests, and serve as bioindicators of air quality. Their complex microbiome likely contributes to their remarkable environmental tolerance (surviving space exposure, extreme desiccation).

questions.question: The Buller's drop mechanism in basidiomycete spore discharge involves:
options: condensation of a small water droplet (Buller's drop) near the hilar appendix that merges with a film of water on the spore, generating surface tension energy that catapults the spore
explosive release of pressurized gas within the basidium
enzymatic digestion of the sterigma attachment point
electrostatic repulsion between the spore and basidium surface
questions.explanation: Basidiospore discharge is one of the most elegant biomechanical processes in nature. Each basidiospore sits atop a tapered projection (sterigma) of the basidium, with a small projection (hilar appendix) at the attachment point. The mechanism: (1) Water vapor condenses on the spore surface, forming a thin adaxial film. (2) Simultaneously, a small spherical water droplet (Buller's drop) forms at the hilar appendix from condensation and/or secretion of hygroscopic sugars. (3) When the Buller's drop grows large enough to touch the adaxial film, surface tension causes them to merge instantaneously, releasing surface energy. (4) This energy propels the spore laterally off the sterigma at an initial velocity of ~1.5 m/s. The spore then falls between the gills by gravity. This mechanism discharges spores at a rate of ~30,000 spores per second from a single mushroom cap. The process requires the precise geometry of gill spacing to prevent spores from impacting the opposing gill surface.

questions.question: Fossilized fungal hyphae and spores from the Ordovician period (~460 MYA) suggest that fungi:
options: evolved only after the colonization of land by plants
may have been among the first organisms to colonize terrestrial environments, possibly predating or co-occurring with early land plants
are exclusively marine organisms that only recently adapted to terrestrial life
evolved from plant roots through a process of dedifferentiation
questions.explanation: Fossil evidence suggests fungi were among the earliest organisms to colonize land. Ordovician fossils (~460 MYA) of terrestrial fungal hyphae and spores predate the earliest definitive macrofossils of land plants. The large Devonian fossil Prototaxites (~400 MYA), once enigmatic, is now interpreted by many researchers as a massive fungal structure up to 8 meters tall—it would have been the tallest organism on land during its time. Molecular clock estimates suggest fungi diverged from their animal sister group approximately 1 billion years ago and may have been present on land long before plants. The early colonization of land by fungi would have been facilitated by their absorptive nutrition (not requiring photosynthesis), their ability to decompose organic matter, and their partnership with cyanobacteria (forming proto-lichens) that could provide photosynthetic carbon. The mycorrhizal partnership may have been essential for early plant land colonization.

questions.question: Saccharomyces cerevisiae (baker's/brewer's yeast) has been instrumental in biological research because:
options: it is the only fungus that can grow in laboratory conditions
it has the largest known eukaryotic genome, providing comprehensive genetic information
it produces antibiotics that prevent contamination in culture
it is a simple unicellular eukaryote with a well-characterized genome, rapid growth, and genetic tractability
questions.explanation: Saccharomyces cerevisiae is one of the most important model organisms in biology. Its value stems from multiple features: (1) Simple unicellular growth with a ~90-minute generation time, enabling rapid experiments. (2) A compact, well-characterized genome (~12 Mb, 6,000 genes) that was the first eukaryotic genome completely sequenced (1996). (3) Easy genetic manipulation including transformation, gene knockouts, and CRISPR editing. (4) The ability to grow as both haploid and diploid, facilitating genetic analysis. (5) Many fundamental eukaryotic cellular processes (cell cycle, DNA replication, protein secretion, signal transduction) are conserved between yeast and humans. Nobel Prizes have been awarded for yeast research including the cell cycle (2001), autophagy (2016), and telomere biology. Additionally, yeast's industrial importance in baking, brewing, and biotechnology (insulin and vaccine production) makes it commercially valuable.

questions.question:
About fungal bioluminescence:
(I) Approximately 80 fungal species are known to produce bioluminescence
(II) Fungal bioluminescence uses a luciferin-luciferase system similar to but distinct from firefly bioluminescence
(III) Bioluminescence in fungi may attract insects that disperse fungal spores
(IV) All basidiomycete mushrooms are bioluminescent
Which are TRUE?
options: TTTF — I, II, and III are true
TTFT — I, II, and IV are true
TFTT — I, III, and IV are true
TTTT — All are true
questions.explanation: Statement I is TRUE: Approximately 80 species of bioluminescent fungi have been documented, all belonging to the Basidiomycota, particularly in the genera Mycena, Omphalotus, Armillaria, and Panellus. Statement II is TRUE: Fungal bioluminescence uses a distinct luciferin-luciferase enzymatic system. The fungal luciferin (3-hydroxyhispidin) is oxidized by a luciferase enzyme in the presence of oxygen to produce light (typically green, ~520 nm wavelength). This system evolved independently from bioluminescence in fireflies, bacteria, and marine organisms. Statement III is TRUE: Evidence suggests bioluminescence may attract nocturnal arthropods (beetles, flies, and other insects) that serve as spore dispersers, particularly for species fruiting in dark forest understory environments. Experimental studies have shown increased arthropod visitation to luminescent versus non-luminescent mushroom models. Statement IV is FALSE: The vast majority of basidiomycete mushrooms are not bioluminescent.

questions.question: Mycoheterotrophic plants such as Monotropa (Indian pipe) obtain their carbon by:
options: photosynthesizing with modified chloroplasts that lack chlorophyll
absorbing dissolved organic carbon directly from soil water
parasitizing mycorrhizal fungi that are connected to photosynthetic trees, effectively exploiting the mycorrhizal network
fixing atmospheric CO2 using a non-photosynthetic enzyme system
questions.explanation: Mycoheterotrophic plants like Monotropa uniflora (Indian pipe) lack chlorophyll and cannot photosynthesize. Instead, they parasitize mycorrhizal fungi—specifically ectomycorrhizal fungi connected to the roots of nearby photosynthetic trees. Carbon flows from the autotrophic tree to the mycorrhizal fungus (as in normal mycorrhizal symbiosis) and then from the fungus to the mycoheterotroph. Isotopic studies using 13C and 14C have confirmed this carbon transfer pathway. Monotropa forms highly specialized associations with specific Russulaceae fungi that simultaneously form ectomycorrhizal connections with surrounding trees. This represents an epiparasitic relationship where the mycoheterotroph exploits an existing mutualism. Mycoheterotrophy has evolved independently over 50 times across plant lineages and provides unique evidence for bidirectional carbon flow in mycorrhizal networks.

questions.question:
Evaluate statements about fungal pathogenesis in humans:
(I) Candida albicans can switch between yeast and hyphal growth forms, enhancing pathogenicity
(II) Aspergillus fumigatus causes invasive aspergillosis primarily in immunocompromised patients
(III) Dermatophytes infect keratinized tissues (skin, hair, nails) using keratinase enzymes
(IV) All fungal infections are easily treated with a single dose of antibacterial antibiotics
Which are TRUE?
options: TTTF — I, II, and III are true
TTFT — I, II, and IV are true
TFTT — I, III, and IV are true
TTTT — All are true
questions.explanation: Statement I is TRUE: Candida albicans is a polymorphic fungus that can switch between yeast (budding) and hyphal (filamentous) growth forms. The hyphal form is more invasive, penetrating tissues and evading immune cells. This morphological switching is a key virulence factor and is regulated by environmental signals including temperature, pH, and serum. Statement II is TRUE: Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common cause of invasive aspergillosis, primarily affecting immunocompromised patients (organ transplant recipients, chemotherapy patients, AIDS patients). Inhaled conidia can germinate in the lungs and invade blood vessels. Statement III is TRUE: Dermatophytes (Trichophyton, Microsporum, Epidermophyton) produce keratinases that digest keratin, the structural protein of skin, hair, and nails. Statement IV is FALSE: Antibacterial antibiotics do not work against fungi. Fungal infections require antifungal drugs (azoles, polyenes, echinocandins) which target fungal-specific structures.

questions.question: A researcher wants to determine which specific fungal species in forest litter are primarily responsible for leaf decomposition. The most informative approach is:
options: Visually identify mushrooms growing on leaf litter and assume they are the primary decomposers
Measure total fungal biomass in the litter over time
Use stable isotope probing: add 13C-labeled leaf litter, then identify fungi that have incorporated the 13C into their biomass using DNA-based methods
Culture fungi from leaf litter on nutrient agar and test each for cellulase activity
questions.explanation: Stable isotope probing (SIP) is a powerful technique for identifying metabolically active decomposers in their natural environment. The approach involves: (1) adding 13C-labeled plant litter (produced by growing plants in 13CO2 atmosphere) to forest soil, (2) after a defined incubation period, extracting total DNA from the litter, (3) separating 'heavy' (13C-enriched) DNA from 'light' (12C) DNA by density gradient ultracentrifugation, and (4) identifying fungi in the heavy DNA fraction by ITS amplicon sequencing or metagenomics. Fungi that have actively consumed and assimilated 13C from the labeled litter will have incorporated 13C into their DNA, which becomes denser. This directly links taxonomic identity to metabolic function in situ, without the biases of culture-based approaches (option D, where most soil fungi are unculturable) or visual identification (option A, where fruiting bodies don't indicate decomposition activity).

questions.question: To determine whether volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from Trichoderma fungi directly promote plant growth independently of their biocontrol activity, the best design is:
options: Grow Trichoderma in direct contact with plant roots and measure growth
Compare plant growth in sterilized versus non-sterilized soil
Apply commercial Trichoderma biocontrol products to field plots and measure crop yield
Use a split-plate system where Trichoderma and the plant share airspace but not soil, with and without a pathogen present, measuring plant growth in a factorial design
questions.explanation: A split-plate system physically separates Trichoderma from the plant while allowing VOC exchange through shared airspace. The factorial design crosses two variables: (1) Trichoderma presence (VOCs present/absent) and (2) pathogen presence (present/absent), creating four treatments: no Trichoderma + no pathogen (control), Trichoderma VOCs + no pathogen (direct growth promotion test), no Trichoderma + pathogen (disease baseline), Trichoderma VOCs + pathogen (combined effects). If plants exposed to Trichoderma VOCs alone (no pathogen) show enhanced growth compared to controls, this demonstrates direct growth-promoting effects of VOCs independent of biocontrol. The physical separation ensures that observed effects are mediated by volatiles rather than direct mycelial contact, competition for nutrients, or other non-volatile mechanisms.

questions.question: Fungal secondary metabolites include which of the following commercially important compounds?
options: Cyclosporine (immunosuppressant), statins (cholesterol-lowering), and penicillin (antibiotic)
Insulin and human growth hormone
Caffeine and nicotine
Aspirin and ibuprofen
questions.explanation: Fungi produce an extraordinary diversity of secondary metabolites with pharmaceutical applications: (1) Cyclosporine, produced by Tolypocladium inflatum, revolutionized organ transplantation by selectively suppressing T-cell-mediated immunity. (2) Statins (lovastatin from Aspergillus terreus, compactin from Penicillium citrinum) inhibit HMG-CoA reductase, lowering cholesterol and becoming among the most prescribed drugs worldwide. (3) Penicillin from Penicillium inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis. Other important fungal metabolites include griseofulvin (antifungal), cephalosporins (antibiotics), mycophenolic acid (immunosuppressant), and ergot alkaloids (migraine treatment). The diversity of fungal secondary metabolites reflects millions of years of chemical warfare among microorganisms competing for resources in soil and other environments.

questions.question: Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (phylum Glomeromycota) form symbioses with approximately what percentage of plant species?
options: Less than 5%
About 25%
Approximately 50%
Over 80%
questions.explanation: Arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) fungi form symbioses with over 80% of all land plant species, making this the most widespread plant-fungal mutualism on Earth. AM fungi penetrate root cortical cells and form highly branched arbuscules that dramatically increase the surface area for nutrient exchange. The fungus provides the plant with mineral nutrients (especially phosphorus, which has limited mobility in soil) and receives photosynthetically derived carbon (sugars and lipids) from the plant. This ancient partnership likely dates to the earliest colonization of land by plants (~450 MYA), and fossil evidence from the Rhynie Chert shows AM-like structures in early Devonian plants. The Glomeromycota are obligate symbionts that cannot complete their life cycle without a plant host, reflecting their deep evolutionary commitment to this mutualistic lifestyle.

questions.question: The basidiocarp (fruiting body) of a typical mushroom-forming basidiomycete consists of:
options: a single multinucleate cell that inflates to form the cap and stalk
loosely arranged monokaryotic hyphae with no organized tissue structure
tightly packed dikaryotic hyphae forming the stipe (stalk), pileus (cap), and gills bearing basidia
photosynthetic tissue in the cap and absorptive tissue in the stalk
questions.explanation: The basidiocarp is a complex reproductive structure composed of interwoven dikaryotic hyphae organized into distinct tissues. The stipe (stalk) provides structural support, composed of longitudinally oriented hyphae. The pileus (cap) provides protection for the reproductive surface. The gills (lamellae) are thin plates hanging from the underside of the cap, bearing the basidia—club-shaped cells where karyogamy and meiosis occur. Each basidium typically produces four basidiospores on horn-like projections called sterigmata. The entire basidiocarp can develop rapidly (overnight in some species) through water absorption and expansion of pre-formed hyphal cells rather than new cell division—a process called cell inflation. Some mushrooms can generate sufficient turgor pressure to push through asphalt. The basidiocarp represents only a tiny fraction of the fungal organism; the vast majority of the fungal body is the underground mycelium.

questions.question: Species richness data for endophytic fungi isolated from tropical versus temperate tree leaves: Tropical trees — average 45 species per tree species; Temperate trees — average 12 species per tree species. Additionally, overlap between endophyte communities of different host species: Tropical — 15% shared species; Temperate — 42% shared species. These patterns suggest:
options: Temperate endophytes are more diverse but less host-specific
Tropical endophyte communities show higher alpha diversity and greater host specificity than temperate communities
Tropical and temperate endophyte communities are identical in structure
Host plant identity has no influence on endophyte community composition
questions.explanation: The data reveals two complementary patterns in endophytic fungal diversity: (1) Higher alpha diversity in tropical hosts (45 vs 12 species per tree species), reflecting the general latitudinal diversity gradient observed across most organism groups, likely driven by greater habitat heterogeneity, higher speciation rates, and longer evolutionary history of tropical ecosystems. (2) Lower community overlap between different host species in the tropics (15% vs 42% shared species), indicating greater host specificity of tropical endophytes. Together, these patterns suggest that tropical endophyte communities are both richer per host and more differentiated between hosts, contributing to very high beta diversity. This may reflect tighter coevolutionary relationships between hosts and endophytes in the species-rich tropical environment, where specialized associations may be favored by intense competition and diverse chemical environments across host species.

questions.question: Measurements of CO2 flux from forest soil with and without fungal activity: Control (with fungi) — 4.2 μmol CO2/m2/s; Fungicide-treated — 1.8 μmol CO2/m2/s; Sterile soil — 0.3 μmol CO2/m2/s. These data indicate that fungi contribute approximately what percentage of total soil respiration?
options: About 10% of soil respiration
About 40-60% of soil respiration
About 90% of soil respiration
Fungi do not contribute measurably to soil respiration
questions.explanation: The data allows estimation of fungal contribution to soil respiration. Total biological soil respiration = 4.2 - 0.3 = 3.9 μmol/m2/s (subtracting abiotic CO2 release from sterile soil). Fungicide-treated soil respiration = 1.8 - 0.3 = 1.5 μmol/m2/s (bacterial/root respiration only). Therefore, fungal respiration = 3.9 - 1.5 = 2.4 μmol/m2/s, representing approximately 62% of biological soil respiration (2.4/3.9). This is consistent with published estimates that fungi contribute 40-60% of total heterotrophic soil respiration in forest ecosystems. Fungi dominate soil carbon cycling because: (1) they are the primary decomposers of plant litter and woody debris, (2) mycorrhizal fungi receive substantial carbon from plant hosts, and (3) fungal biomass in forest soils typically exceeds bacterial biomass. This finding has important implications for understanding global carbon cycling and predicting soil carbon responses to climate change.

questions.question: Molecular phylogenetic studies place fungi closest to which group of eukaryotes?
options: Plants (Viridiplantae)
Red algae (Rhodophyta)
Animals (Metazoa)
Brown algae (Phaeophyta)
questions.explanation: Molecular phylogenetic analyses consistently place fungi as more closely related to animals than to plants. Fungi and animals together form the clade Opisthokonta, named for the posterior (opistho) flagellum (kontos) found in the motile cells of both groups. Additional shared characters include: (1) flat mitochondrial cristae (plants have tubular cristae); (2) storage of glycogen as a reserve carbohydrate (plants store starch); (3) the synthesis of chitin (fungi use it for cell walls, animals for exoskeletons); (4) similar metabolic pathways including the lysine biosynthetic pathway. The opisthokont clade is strongly supported by ribosomal RNA sequences, protein-coding genes, and genomic data. This relationship means that fungi share a more recent common ancestor with humans than with mushrooms share with the plants they grow among.

questions.question: Pilobolus, the 'shotgun fungus,' disperses its sporangia by:
options: releasing spores into wind currents from tall stalks
attracting flies with foul odor to carry spores on their bodies
using phototropic sporangiophores that aim and explosively discharge sporangia toward light at velocities exceeding 25 m/s
producing floating sporangia that travel along water films
questions.explanation: Pilobolus (Mucorales) has evolved one of the most remarkable dispersal mechanisms in nature. This coprophilous (dung-inhabiting) fungus grows on herbivore dung and needs to project its sporangia away from the dung to reach vegetation that herbivores will eat. The sporangiophore is positively phototropic, bending toward light to aim the sporangium. Beneath the black sporangium, a subsporangial vesicle accumulates osmotically active solutes, generating tremendous turgor pressure. When the vesicle ruptures, the sporangium is launched at initial accelerations exceeding 20,000g—one of the highest accelerations in any biological system. The projectile can travel up to 2.5 meters. The sticky sporangium adheres to grass blades, where it is consumed by herbivores, passes through the digestive tract, and germinates on fresh dung. This completes a lifecycle optimized around herbivore ecology.

questions.question: A study measures decomposition rates of different substrates by various fungi: Cellulose by brown rot fungi — 85% in 6 months; Cellulose by white rot fungi — 90% in 6 months; Lignin by brown rot fungi — 5% in 6 months; Lignin by white rot fungi — 75% in 6 months. This data demonstrates:
options: White rot fungi are distinguished by their ability to decompose lignin, while brown rot fungi primarily attack cellulose
Both fungal types decompose all substrates equally
Brown rot fungi are more efficient decomposers overall
Neither type can decompose cellulose effectively
questions.explanation: The data clearly shows that both brown rot and white rot fungi can effectively decompose cellulose (85% vs 90%), but they differ dramatically in their ability to decompose lignin (5% vs 75%). White rot fungi possess ligninolytic enzymes (lignin peroxidase, manganese peroxidase, laccase) that generate free radicals capable of breaking lignin's irregular bonds. Brown rot fungi lack these enzymes and instead use a Fenton chemistry-based mechanism (hydroxyl radicals from iron and hydrogen peroxide) that modifies lignin but does not fully decompose it. This is why brown rot leaves behind a modified lignin residue (brown, crumbly 'brown rot') while white rot removes both lignin and cellulose, leaving behind white cellulose residue. The distinction has important ecological implications: brown rot residues contribute to stable soil carbon (humus), while white rot achieves more complete carbon mineralization.

questions.question: The concept of quorum sensing in fungi involves:
options: communication between individual fungal cells using small signaling molecules to coordinate group behaviors such as biofilm formation and morphological switching
long-distance communication between separate fungal colonies via airborne spores
sensing the number of host cells available for infection
measuring soil pH to determine optimal growth conditions
questions.explanation: Quorum sensing (QS) in fungi is a cell-density-dependent communication system that coordinates multicellular behaviors. The best-characterized fungal QS system is in Candida albicans, which uses farnesol and tyrosol as signaling molecules. At high cell densities, farnesol accumulates and inhibits the yeast-to-hypha transition, while tyrosol promotes it at low densities. This regulation affects biofilm formation—structured communities of cells attached to surfaces and embedded in an extracellular matrix. Candida biofilms on medical devices are clinically significant because they are highly resistant to antifungal drugs and immune clearance. Other fungi also show QS-like behaviors: the phytopathogen Ophiostoma produces dimorphism-regulating factors, and Cryptococcus neoformans uses peptide signals. Fungal QS parallels bacterial QS systems but uses different signal molecules, representing convergent evolution of social coordination mechanisms.

questions.question: Which statement about fungal sexual reproduction is correct?
options: Many fungi have cryptic sexual cycles that were only discovered through genomic analysis revealing mating-type genes
All fungi reproduce sexually and never produce asexual spores
Fungal sexual reproduction always requires a distinct male and female organism
Sexual reproduction in fungi always produces diploid offspring that remain diploid
questions.explanation: Many fungi that were classified as 'Deuteromycota' or 'Fungi Imperfecti' because no sexual stage had been observed were later found to possess complete mating-type gene loci in their genomes, suggesting they retain the capacity for sexual reproduction. In some cases, sexual stages were subsequently discovered through careful laboratory crossing experiments using appropriate mating types and conditions. Notable examples include Aspergillus fumigatus (sexual stage discovered in 2009 after being considered asexual for over a century) and Penicillium chrysogenum. Genomic analysis has revealed MAT locus genes even in species where sexual reproduction has never been observed, suggesting either very rare sexual cycles, specific environmental triggers not replicated in the laboratory, or recent loss of sexuality. This demonstrates the power of genomics in revealing biological capabilities hidden from traditional observational approaches.

questions.question: Mycorrhizal associations are classified into several types. How do arbuscular mycorrhizae (AM, or endomycorrhizae) differ structurally from ectomycorrhizae (ECM)?
options: AM and ECM are structurally identical
Both types form external fruiting bodies on root surfaces
ECM fungi penetrate cells while AM fungi remain outside

AM fungi (Glomeromycota) penetrate root cortical cell walls and form branched structures (arbuscules) inside cells for nutrient exchange, while ECM fungi (mainly Basidiomycota and Ascomycota) form a dense hyphal sheath around roots and a Hartig net between cortical cells but do not penetrate cell walls
questions.explanation: AM and ECM represent distinct symbiotic architectures: (1) Arbuscular mycorrhizae (AM): Formed by Glomeromycota (obligate symbionts). Hyphae penetrate root cortical cell walls (but not plasma membrane) to form highly branched arbuscules (tree-like structures)—the primary site of nutrient exchange. Also form vesicles (lipid storage). No visible external structures (no sheath or fruiting bodies). Colonize ~80% of plant species. (2) Ectomycorrhizae (ECM): Formed mainly by Basidiomycota and Ascomycota. Hyphae form a mantle (sheath) around root tips and grow between cortical cells forming the Hartig net—but never penetrate cell walls. Produce visible fruiting bodies (mushrooms, truffles). Associate primarily with temperate/boreal tree families (Pinaceae, Fagaceae, Betulaceae). (3) Functional differences: AM fungi primarily provide phosphorus; ECM fungi provide both phosphorus and nitrogen (some can access organic N directly via protease secretion). (4) Ecological pattern: AM dominates in tropical forests and grasslands; ECM dominates in boreal and temperate forests. The ECM-AM boundary affects nutrient cycling, decomposition rates, and soil carbon storage.

questions.question: The ascus of Ascomycota is functionally important because it is the site of:
options: asexual spore (conidium) production on conidiophores
hyphal anastomosis and cytoplasmic mixing
nutrient absorption from the substrate
karyogamy, meiosis, and typically one post-meiotic mitosis, producing eight ascospores
questions.explanation: The ascus is the defining structure of Ascomycota. It is a sac-shaped cell in which the final stages of sexual reproduction occur. Within the ascus: (1) karyogamy—fusion of the two haploid nuclei from the dikaryotic state to form a transient diploid nucleus; (2) meiosis—the diploid nucleus undergoes meiosis to produce four haploid nuclei; (3) post-meiotic mitosis—typically one mitotic division produces eight haploid nuclei, each incorporated into an ascospore. The eight ascospores are arranged linearly within the ascus in an order that directly reflects the meiotic divisions, making the ascus valuable for tetrad analysis in genetics. Asci may be borne in various types of fruiting bodies: apothecia (cup-shaped), perithecia (flask-shaped), or cleistothecia (closed spheres). The turgor-based active discharge of ascospores is a hallmark of many ascomycetes.

questions.question: To test whether a fungal endophyte confers drought tolerance to its grass host, the most rigorous experimental design would be:
options: Compare growth of endophyte-infected and endophyte-free grass clones under controlled drought stress in a factorial design with adequate replication
Observe grass populations in a drought year and note which plants survive
Apply the endophyte to soil near stressed grass plants and observe recovery
Measure endophyte abundance in grass roots across a rainfall gradient
questions.explanation: The most rigorous approach uses a factorial design comparing endophyte-infected (E+) and endophyte-free (E-) grass clones under both well-watered and drought conditions with adequate replication. E- clones can be created by treating seeds with systemic fungicide or heat, then verified as endophyte-free by microscopy. Using clonal material controls for host plant genetic variation. The four treatment groups are: E+ well-watered, E+ drought, E- well-watered, and E- drought. Measuring growth, water use efficiency, osmotic adjustment, and survival across these treatments allows determination of both main effects and interaction effects. A significant endophyte x water interaction would demonstrate that the endophyte specifically enhances performance under drought conditions.

questions.question: Antifungal susceptibility testing results for a clinical Candida isolate: Fluconazole MIC — 64 μg/mL (resistant); Amphotericin B MIC — 0.5 μg/mL (susceptible); Caspofungin MIC — 0.25 μg/mL (susceptible); Flucytosine MIC — 16 μg/mL (intermediate). Which treatment strategy is most appropriate?
options: Use fluconazole at a higher dose since the organism is resistant at standard doses
Use amphotericin B or caspofungin, which show susceptibility, and avoid fluconazole
Use flucytosine alone since it shows intermediate susceptibility
Do not treat, as some resistance indicates the infection is untreatable
questions.explanation: Antifungal susceptibility testing (AST) guides treatment decisions by identifying which drugs can achieve sufficient concentrations at the site of infection to inhibit or kill the pathogen. The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) is compared to established breakpoints. For this Candida isolate: Fluconazole MIC of 64 μg/mL indicates resistance—the drug cannot achieve sufficient tissue concentrations to be effective, so it should be avoided. Amphotericin B (MIC 0.5 μg/mL) and caspofungin (MIC 0.25 μg/mL) show clear susceptibility and are appropriate choices. Amphotericin B targets ergosterol in fungal membranes, while caspofungin inhibits beta-1,3-glucan synthase in fungal cell walls—these distinct mechanisms explain how an organism can be resistant to one antifungal class while susceptible to others. Flucytosine at intermediate susceptibility could be used in combination therapy but should not be used alone due to rapid resistance development.

questions.question: Carbon-14 dating and growth ring analysis of a large Armillaria colony reveals: Colony diameter — 600 m; Average annual radial growth — 0.75 m; Estimated minimum age — 400 years; Number of tree hosts killed — approximately 250 over the colony's lifetime. The killing rate of about 0.6 trees per year suggests:
options: The fungus is an aggressive pathogen that rapidly decimates all trees in its path
The colony will die within the next decade due to lack of hosts
The fungus has no impact on forest health
The fungus acts as a slow, chronic pathogen that gradually kills weakened trees over extended periods, functioning partly as a selective agent in forest dynamics
questions.explanation: A killing rate of approximately 0.6 trees per year over 400 years for a colony covering 28 hectares indicates that Armillaria acts as a chronic, slow pathogen rather than an acute epidemic disease. At this rate, the fungus selectively removes approximately one tree every 1.7 years from its territory—primarily targeting stressed, suppressed, or weakened individuals. This pattern positions Armillaria as an ecological equivalent of a slow-acting predator that culls the weakest members of the population. By selectively killing stressed trees, Armillaria contributes to forest gap dynamics: tree death creates canopy openings that allow regeneration, increase light availability for understory plants, and create standing dead wood (snags) and downed wood that provides habitat for many organisms.

questions.question: The concept of 'wood wide web' refers to:
options: the internet infrastructure built from wooden utility poles
the branching pattern of tree roots visible above ground
spider webs found in forest canopies
interconnected mycorrhizal fungal networks in forest soil that facilitate nutrient and signal exchange between trees
questions.explanation: The 'wood wide web' is a popular term for common mycorrhizal networks (CMNs)—underground fungal networks that connect the roots of multiple trees and plants in a forest. Ectomycorrhizal fungi, in particular, form extensive hyphal networks that can link trees of the same or different species. Research has demonstrated that these networks can transfer carbon from 'donor' trees (often large, well-lit trees) to 'receiver' trees (often shaded seedlings), potentially subsidizing the growth of understory plants. The networks may also transfer nitrogen, phosphorus, water, and even defense signaling molecules. Some researchers argue that old-growth 'mother trees' serve as network hubs that support regeneration. However, the extent and significance of CMN resource transfer in natural forests remains actively debated.

questions.question: The Dikarya clade encompasses which two fungal phyla?
options: Chytridiomycota and Zygomycota
Blastocladiomycota and Neocallimastigomycota
Glomeromycota and Microsporidia
Ascomycota and Basidiomycota
questions.explanation: The Dikarya is a well-supported monophyletic clade comprising the Ascomycota (sac fungi) and Basidiomycota (club fungi). The name refers to the dikaryotic phase that is prominent in the life cycles of both phyla—a stage where cells contain two genetically distinct haploid nuclei (n+n) that divide synchronously. Together, Ascomycota (~64,000 species) and Basidiomycota (~32,000 species) constitute the vast majority of described fungal species. They share additional synapomorphies including: septate hyphae with regular cross-walls containing central pores, similar enzyme systems for wood decomposition, and molecular phylogenetic markers. The Dikarya is consistently recovered as monophyletic in molecular analyses, and the group represents the most diverse and ecologically important fungal radiation, including most decomposers, mycorrhizal fungi, plant pathogens, lichens, and edible mushrooms.

questions.question: Mycotoxins such as aflatoxins (produced by Aspergillus flavus) are dangerous because they:
options: cause immediate allergic reactions in all exposed individuals
only affect insects and have no impact on human health
dissolve plastics in food packaging, releasing toxic compounds
are potent carcinogens that intercalate into DNA and cause liver cancer at chronic low-dose exposure
questions.explanation: Aflatoxins produced by Aspergillus flavus and A. parasiticus are among the most potent naturally occurring carcinogens known. Aflatoxin B1, the most toxic, is metabolized by liver cytochrome P450 enzymes into a reactive epoxide that covalently binds to DNA, causing a characteristic G-to-T transversion mutation in the p53 tumor suppressor gene (at codon 249). Chronic exposure to low levels of aflatoxins in contaminated grains, peanuts, and tree nuts is a major cause of hepatocellular carcinoma (liver cancer), particularly in tropical developing countries where food storage conditions favor Aspergillus growth. Aflatoxin exposure synergizes with hepatitis B virus infection to dramatically increase liver cancer risk. The economic impact is enormous—billions of dollars of crops are lost annually to aflatoxin contamination. Regulatory limits for aflatoxins in food are set at parts-per-billion levels due to their extreme toxicity.

questions.question: The phenomenon of heterokaryosis in fungi refers to:
options: the presence of nuclei with identical genomes in all cells
the presence of genetically different nuclei within the same mycelium or cell
the fusion of nuclei from two different species creating a hybrid
the duplication of the entire genome within a single nucleus
questions.explanation: Heterokaryosis—the coexistence of genetically different nuclei within the same cytoplasm—is a distinctive feature of fungal biology made possible by the syncytial (coenocytic or septate-with-pores) nature of fungal hyphae. Heterokaryosis can arise through: (1) hyphal anastomosis (fusion) between genetically different mycelia of the same species, (2) mutation in one nucleus but not others, or (3) the dikaryotic condition in Dikarya. Heterokaryosis provides a form of genetic flexibility analogous to diploidy: different nuclear genotypes can complement each other's deficiencies, allowing the mycelium to adapt to heterogeneous environments. Nuclear ratios can shift in response to environmental conditions, providing rapid phenotypic adaptation without genetic change. This 'somatic hybridization' through hyphal fusion is unique to fungi and contributes to their remarkable ecological versatility.

questions.question: Saprotrophic fungi play an irreplaceable ecological role as:
options: primary producers converting inorganic carbon to organic molecules
primary consumers that regulate herbivore populations
nitrogen-fixing organisms that enrich soil fertility
the only organisms capable of fully decomposing lignin, recycling carbon and nutrients locked in woody plant material
questions.explanation: Saprotrophic fungi are the primary decomposers of dead organic matter in terrestrial ecosystems, and white-rot basidiomycetes are the only organisms known to fully decompose lignin, the complex phenolic polymer that gives wood its rigidity and resistance to decay. Lignin is the second most abundant organic polymer on Earth (after cellulose) and contains approximately 30% of the carbon in terrestrial plant biomass. Without fungal lignin decomposition, dead woody material would accumulate indefinitely, locking up carbon and nutrients. The enzyme systems responsible—lignin peroxidases, manganese peroxidases, and laccases—generate highly reactive free radicals that break lignin's irregular, non-hydrolyzable bonds. The evolution of lignin-degrading enzymes in white-rot fungi during the Permian period may have contributed to the end of the Carboniferous coal-forming period.

questions.question: Penicillium, the fungus that produces the antibiotic penicillin, belongs to which phylum?
options: Basidiomycota
Zygomycota
Ascomycota
Chytridiomycota
questions.explanation: Penicillium is a member of the Ascomycota, the largest fungal phylum (~64,000 known species). The genus name refers to the brush-like arrangement (penicillus = 'little brush') of its conidiophores—specialized hyphae that bear chains of asexual spores (conidia). Alexander Fleming's 1928 discovery that Penicillium notatum (now P. rubens) inhibited bacterial growth led to the development of penicillin, one of the most important medical discoveries in history. Penicillin works by inhibiting bacterial cell wall synthesis (specifically the cross-linking of peptidoglycan by transpeptidase enzymes), and it does not affect fungi because fungal cell walls contain chitin rather than peptidoglycan. Other important Ascomycota include Saccharomyces (baker's/brewer's yeast), Aspergillus, Neurospora (bread mold, important model organism), and truffles.

questions.question: Trichoderma species are used as biological control agents in agriculture because they:
options: fix atmospheric nitrogen, reducing the need for fertilizers
produce seeds that outcompete weeds for light and water
parasitize and kill plant-pathogenic fungi through mycoparasitism and competition
attract beneficial insects that pollinate crop plants
questions.explanation: Trichoderma species are widely used as biocontrol agents against plant-pathogenic fungi. Their mechanisms of action include: (1) Mycoparasitism—Trichoderma hyphae actively seek, coil around, and penetrate pathogenic fungal hyphae, secreting cell-wall-degrading enzymes (chitinases, glucanases, proteases) that lyse the pathogen. (2) Competition for nutrients and space, preventing pathogen establishment. (3) Antibiosis—production of volatile and non-volatile antibiotics (trichodermin, gliovirin, peptaibols) that inhibit pathogen growth. (4) Induction of systemic resistance in the host plant, priming plant defense responses against subsequent pathogen attack. (5) Enhancement of plant growth through production of auxin-like compounds and improved nutrient uptake. Trichoderma-based biocontrol products are among the most commercially successful biological fungicides, used against pathogens including Rhizoctonia, Pythium, Fusarium, and Sclerotinia.

questions.question: A study compares ergosterol content (a proxy for fungal biomass) in decomposing oak leaf litter over 24 months: Month 0 — 0 mg/g; Month 3 — 2.5 mg/g; Month 6 — 5.8 mg/g; Month 12 — 8.1 mg/g; Month 18 — 4.3 mg/g; Month 24 — 2.1 mg/g. The peak at 12 months followed by decline most likely reflects:
options: seasonal variation in temperature with no biological significance
contamination of samples at the 12-month collection point
initial fungal colonization and biomass increase as easily decomposable substrates are consumed, followed by decline as recalcitrant compounds remain and resources become limiting
death of all fungi due to accumulation of toxic decomposition products
questions.explanation: The ergosterol dynamics reveal the classic pattern of fungal succession during litter decomposition. Initial months (0-12) show increasing fungal biomass as successive waves of fungal species colonize and consume increasingly complex substrates: first sugar fungi (Mucor, Rhizopus) consume simple sugars and amino acids, then cellulolytic fungi (Trichoderma, Chaetomium) degrade cellulose and hemicellulose, and finally lignin-degrading basidiomycetes attack the most recalcitrant compounds. The peak at 12 months represents maximum fungal activity when cellulose degradation is most active. The subsequent decline (12-24 months) occurs because: (1) easily decomposable substrates have been consumed, leaving increasingly recalcitrant lignin-humus complexes; (2) total substrate mass has decreased significantly, supporting less biomass; and (3) the remaining organic matter has lower energy yield per unit mass. This pattern is well-documented in litter decomposition studies across ecosystems.

questions.question: Predatory fungi such as Arthrobotrys capture nematodes using:
options: toxic spores that are inhaled by the nematode
chemical signals that attract nematodes to toxic substrates
adhesive knobs, constricting rings, or adhesive networks that trap nematodes mechanically
parasitic spores injected directly into nematode eggs
questions.explanation: Predatory (nematophagous) fungi have evolved sophisticated trapping devices to capture and consume soil nematodes. Arthrobotrys species produce several types of traps: (1) Adhesive networks—three-dimensional hyphal loops coated with adhesive that entangle passing nematodes. (2) Constricting rings—three-celled ring structures that inflate rapidly (in 0.1 seconds) when a nematode enters, gripping the worm tightly. (3) Adhesive knobs—sticky hyphal branches that adhere to nematode cuticle. Once captured, the fungus penetrates the nematode cuticle with specialized hyphae and digests the internal tissues. These trapping structures are typically induced by the presence of nematodes or their chemical signals, representing a remarkable example of phenotypic plasticity. Nematode-trapping fungi supplement their nitrogen nutrition through predation, particularly in nitrogen-poor environments.

questions.question: Lichen is a composite organism consisting of:
options: two species of fungi growing intertwined
a plant root and its associated mycorrhizal fungus
a fungus (mycobiont) and one or more photosynthetic partners (photobiont: green algae and/or cyanobacteria)
a parasitic fungus and its insect host
questions.explanation: Lichens are composite organisms formed by a symbiotic association between a fungus (the mycobiont, usually an ascomycete) and one or more photosynthetic partners (photobionts). The photobiont may be a green alga (most commonly Trebouxia), a cyanobacterium (such as Nostoc), or both. The fungal partner provides the structural framework of the lichen thallus and protects the photobiont from desiccation and excessive light. The photobiont provides photosynthetically produced carbohydrates (glucose from green algae, or glucose and nitrogen-fixing capability from cyanobacteria). Recent research has revealed that many lichens also contain basidiomycete yeasts in their cortex, adding a third fungal partner to the traditional two-partner model. Lichens are remarkable colonizers of harsh environments including bare rock, arctic tundra, and desert crusts.

questions.question: The Ophiocordyceps unilateralis species complex ('zombie ant fungus') manipulates ant behavior by:
options: infecting the ant's visual system, causing blindness and random wandering
killing the ant instantly and using its body as a passive dispersal platform
releasing pheromones that attract the ant to the fungus's fruiting body
producing compounds that alter the ant's neurotransmitter levels, compelling it to climb to an elevated position, bite a leaf vein, and die in a position optimal for spore dispersal
questions.explanation: Ophiocordyceps unilateralis is a remarkable example of parasite-induced behavioral manipulation. The fungus infects carpenter ants through spore attachment and penetration of the cuticle. As the infection progresses, fungal cells proliferate throughout the ant's body, including surrounding (but notably not destroying) the brain. The fungus produces a cocktail of bioactive compounds that alter the ant's behavior: the infected ant leaves its colony, climbs to an elevated position (typically 20-30 cm above the forest floor), and bites down on a leaf vein or twig with a 'death grip' before dying. This elevated, humid microhabitat is optimal for the fungus to produce its fruiting body (stroma), which erupts from the ant's head and releases spores onto ants passing below. Recent research has shown the fungal cells form networks around the ant's muscle fibers, directly controlling the mandibles, while the brain remains relatively uninfected—the fungus manipulates behavior peripherally rather than centrally.

questions.question:
Consider statements about fungal genetics and genomics:
(I) The yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae was the first eukaryote to have its complete genome sequenced
(II) Fungi typically have small, compact genomes compared to plants and animals
(III) Horizontal gene transfer has been documented between fungi and their plant hosts
(IV) All fungi are strictly haploid throughout their entire life cycle
Which are TRUE?
options: TTTF — I, II, and III are true
TTFT — I, II, and IV are true
TFTT — I, III, and IV are true
TFTF — I and III are true
questions.explanation: Statement I is TRUE: The complete genome of S. cerevisiae was published in 1996, making it the first eukaryotic organism to have its genome fully sequenced. The genome is ~12 Mb with approximately 6,000 protein-coding genes across 16 chromosomes. Statement II is TRUE: Fungal genomes are generally compact, ranging from ~2.5 Mb (Encephalitozoon) to ~180 Mb (some Puccinia species), with most falling in the 25-50 Mb range. This is much smaller than typical plant (~500 Mb-150 Gb) or animal (~500 Mb-3 Gb) genomes, reflecting less repetitive DNA and fewer introns. Statement III is TRUE: Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) between fungi and plants has been documented in several cases, including transfer of biosynthetic gene clusters and transposable elements. Statement IV is FALSE: Fungi are not strictly haploid. Most fungi have a haploid vegetative phase, but the dikaryotic phase (n+n) in Dikarya and the brief diploid phase during sexual reproduction represent non-haploid states.

questions.question: The rapid spread of wheat stem rust race Ug99, first detected in Uganda in 1999, poses a threat to global food security because:
options: it produces toxins that make wheat grain poisonous to humans
it kills all insects that would normally pollinate wheat
it overcomes the Sr31 resistance gene present in approximately 80% of the world's wheat cultivars
it permanently sterilizes the soil, preventing future wheat cultivation
questions.explanation: Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici race TTKSK (Ug99) is a virulent race of wheat stem rust that overcomes the Sr31 resistance gene, which had been widely deployed in wheat breeding programs worldwide. Approximately 80-90% of the world's wheat varieties carry Sr31-based resistance, meaning Ug99 can potentially infect the vast majority of global wheat production. Since its discovery in Uganda, Ug99 has spread to eastern Africa, the Middle East, and has been detected as far as Iran. Wind-dispersed urediniospores can travel hundreds of kilometers, threatening wheat-growing regions across Asia. This represents a classic example of the 'boom and bust' cycle in plant breeding, where widespread deployment of a single resistance gene creates strong selection pressure for pathogen races that can overcome it. International efforts to develop multi-gene resistance strategies are underway.

questions.question:
About the Microsporidia:
(I) Microsporidia are now classified as highly reduced fungi based on molecular phylogenetic evidence
(II) They are obligate intracellular parasites with extremely reduced genomes
(III) Microsporidia possess large mitochondria with active oxidative phosphorylation
(IV) They infect a wide range of hosts including insects, fish, and immunocompromised humans
Which are TRUE?
options: TTFT — I, II, and IV are true
TTTF — I, II, and III are true
TFTT — I, III, and IV are true
TTTT — All are true
questions.explanation: Statement I is TRUE: Molecular phylogenetics has placed Microsporidia within the fungal kingdom, likely as an early-diverging lineage or sister to the Dikarya. They were previously classified as protists but ribosomal RNA, tubulin, and other molecular markers confirm their fungal affiliation. Statement II is TRUE: Microsporidia are obligate intracellular parasites with among the smallest eukaryotic genomes known (~2.3 Mb in Encephalitozoon intestinalis), reflecting massive gene loss associated with their parasitic lifestyle. Statement III is FALSE: Microsporidia have lost mitochondria entirely, possessing only vestigial organelles called mitosomes that no longer perform oxidative phosphorylation. They rely entirely on host ATP through nucleotide transporters stolen via HGT from bacteria. Statement IV is TRUE: Microsporidia infect diverse animal hosts including insects (important in silkworm diseases), fish, and immunocompromised humans (especially AIDS patients, causing microsporidiosis).

questions.question: Dikaryotic hyphae, characteristic of many Basidiomycota and Ascomycota, contain:
options: a single haploid nucleus per cell
a single diploid nucleus resulting from immediate karyogamy
two genetically distinct haploid nuclei per cell that divide in synchrony
multiple polyploid nuclei from repeated endomitosis
questions.explanation: The dikaryotic condition (n+n) is a distinctive feature of the Dikarya (Ascomycota and Basidiomycota). Following plasmogamy (fusion of cytoplasm from two compatible mating types), the two haploid nuclei coexist in each cell without immediately fusing. These paired nuclei divide synchronously during hyphal growth, maintained by specialized structures: clamp connections in Basidiomycota and crozier formation in Ascomycota. The dikaryotic phase can persist for extended periods—in some Basidiomycota, the dikaryotic mycelium is the dominant vegetative stage, lasting years before forming fruiting bodies. Karyogamy (nuclear fusion to form a transient diploid) occurs only in specialized reproductive structures (basidia or asci). This separation of plasmogamy and karyogamy in time is unique among eukaryotes and may provide some advantages of diploidy (complementation of deleterious alleles) while maintaining the flexibility of haploidy.

questions.question: Endophytic fungi that colonize plant tissues without causing disease may benefit their host plants by:
options: competing with the plant for light and water resources
preventing the plant from reproducing to conserve resources
replacing the plant's mitochondria with more efficient fungal mitochondria
producing toxic alkaloids that deter herbivores and enhance plant drought tolerance
questions.explanation: Endophytic fungi live within plant tissues (particularly leaves and stems) without causing visible disease symptoms. Many endophytes form mutualistic relationships with their host plants, providing several benefits: (1) Production of toxic alkaloids (ergot alkaloids, lolines, peramine) that deter herbivorous insects and grazing mammals—this is well-documented in grass endophytes (Epichloe/Neotyphodium species in fescue and ryegrass). (2) Enhanced drought tolerance through osmotic adjustment and improved root function. (3) Increased resistance to pathogens through competition, antibiotic production, and induction of host defense responses. (4) Enhanced nutrient acquisition. In return, the endophyte receives photosynthetic carbon and a protected habitat. The ecological and agricultural importance of endophytes is increasingly recognized, with endophyte-enhanced grass cultivars used in turfgrass and forage production for improved pest resistance.

questions.question:
About mycorrhizal symbioses:
(I) Ectomycorrhizal fungi form a mantle around the root and a Hartig net between cortical cells, but do not penetrate cell walls
(II) Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi penetrate root cortical cell walls but not the plasma membrane
(III) Mycorrhizal networks can transfer nutrients between connected plants ('wood wide web')
(IV) Mycorrhizal associations always benefit the plant and never the fungus
Which are TRUE?
options: TTTF — I, II, and III are true
TTFT — I, II, and IV are true
TFTT — I, III, and IV are true
TTTT — All are true
questions.explanation: Statement I is TRUE: Ectomycorrhizal (ECM) fungi form a dense hyphal sheath (mantle) around root tips and extend hyphae between cortical cells forming the Hartig net—a network of intercellular hyphae that increases the surface area for nutrient exchange. ECM fungi do not penetrate root cell walls. Statement II is TRUE: Arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) fungi penetrate the cell wall of root cortical cells (but not the plasma membrane) to form arbuscules—highly branched structures enclosed within an invagination of the host cell membrane, creating an enormous surface area for nutrient exchange. Statement III is TRUE: Common mycorrhizal networks (CMNs) can connect multiple plants of the same or different species, allowing transfer of carbon, nutrients, and even defense signals between plants—a phenomenon sometimes called the 'wood wide web.' Statement IV is FALSE: Mycorrhizal associations are mutualistic—both partners benefit. The fungus receives carbon (sugars, lipids) from the plant.

questions.question: Aspergillus niger is industrially important for the production of:
options: penicillin antibiotic for medical use
citric acid, used as a food additive and in numerous industrial applications
ethanol for biofuel production
recombinant human insulin
questions.explanation: Aspergillus niger is the primary industrial organism for citric acid production, generating over 2 million tonnes annually worldwide. Citric acid (C6H8O7) is a tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediate that A. niger accumulates in large quantities when grown under specific conditions (excess sugar, limited trace metals, low pH). Industrial fermentation uses submerged culture in large bioreactors with sucrose or molasses as the carbon source. Citric acid has diverse applications: food and beverage acidulant (soft drinks, candies), pharmaceutical excipient, cleaning agent, and industrial chelating agent. A. niger is also used to produce other organic acids (gluconic acid, itaconic acid), various enzymes (amylases, pectinases, proteases), and as a platform for heterologous protein production. Its GRAS (Generally Recognized as Safe) status facilitates food-grade applications.

questions.question: Rust fungi (order Pucciniales) are remarkable parasites because many species:
options: can infect only bacterial hosts and have no impact on plants
can photosynthesize independently without a host
are the only fungi that produce seeds for reproduction
require two unrelated host species to complete their complex life cycle involving up to five spore stages
questions.explanation: Rust fungi (Pucciniales) have among the most complex life cycles of any organisms, with heteroecious species requiring two unrelated host species and producing up to five distinct spore types. Wheat stem rust (Puccinia graminis) exemplifies this: (1) Basidiospores infect barberry (Berberis), producing (2) pycniospores and receptive hyphae for sexual reproduction, then (3) aeciospores that infect wheat, producing (4) urediniospores (repeating asexual spores that cause epidemic spread on wheat), and finally (5) teliospores that overwinter, undergo karyogamy and meiosis, and produce basidiospores to complete the cycle. This alternation between hosts separated the sexual and asexual phases, possibly as an adaptation to avoid host immune responses. Understanding this life cycle was crucial for developing rust-resistant wheat varieties and was a milestone in plant pathology.

questions.question: A conservation biologist wants to assess whether Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) is the primary cause of amphibian population declines in a region. The strongest evidence would come from:
options: A combination of Koch's postulates in controlled experiments (isolating Bd from sick frogs, culturing it, re-infecting healthy frogs, re-isolating Bd) plus field epidemiological data showing Bd prevalence preceding population decline
Finding Bd DNA on the skin of dead frogs
Observing that frog populations decline during wet seasons when Bd might be more active
Reading published reports of Bd causing declines in other regions
questions.explanation: Establishing causation between a pathogen and population decline requires both experimental and epidemiological evidence. Koch's postulates (modified for wildlife disease) provide the experimental framework: (1) isolate Bd from diseased frogs, (2) culture the pathogen, (3) expose healthy frogs to cultured Bd and demonstrate disease development, (4) re-isolate Bd from experimentally infected frogs. Complementary field epidemiological data should show: temporal association (Bd detection preceding decline), spatial association (decline occurring where Bd is present), dose-response relationship (higher Bd loads correlating with greater mortality), and consistency across multiple populations. Finding Bd DNA alone (option A) shows association but not causation. Seasonal correlation (option C) is circumstantial. Reports from other regions (option D) support plausibility but not local causation.

questions.question: Truffles (Tuber spp.) form their fruiting bodies underground. Their spore dispersal depends on:
options: wind carrying spores through soil pores to the surface
water percolation through soil carrying spores to streams
animals (primarily mammals) that detect the truffle's aroma, dig it up, eat it, and disperse spores in their feces
explosive discharge that propels spores through soil to the surface
questions.explanation: Truffles are hypogeous (underground) ascomycete fruiting bodies that have lost the ability to actively discharge their spores. Instead, they have evolved to attract animal dispersers through production of volatile organic compounds that create their distinctive and potent aroma. These aromatics include dimethyl sulfide, 2-methylbutanal, and androstenol (a compound also found in boar saliva, which may explain why pigs are effective truffle hunters). Squirrels, voles, wild boar, deer, and other mammals detect truffle aromas through the soil, excavate and consume the fruiting bodies, and disperse the thick-walled ascospores through their feces. This animal dispersal strategy has evolved independently in multiple fungal lineages and represents an example of convergent evolution in response to the constraints of subterranean fruiting.

questions.question: Growth rate measurements for Armillaria ostoyae (honey fungus) in forest soil: Annual radial expansion — 0.5-1.0 m/year; Current colony extent — 965 hectares; Estimated age — 2,400 years; Estimated biomass — 6,000 tonnes. These data support Armillaria as:
options: the fastest-growing organism on Earth
evidence that fungi are immortal and cannot die of natural causes
the most nutritionally efficient organism, requiring minimal resources
potentially the largest and one of the oldest living organisms known
questions.explanation: The Armillaria ostoyae colony in Oregon's Malheur National Forest, spanning 965 hectares (approximately 3.7 square miles) with an estimated age of 2,400 years and biomass of 6,000 tonnes, is considered one of the largest and oldest living organisms on Earth. The colony grows through the soil as a network of rhizomorphs (root-like hyphal cords) that connect and parasitize tree roots. The growth rate of 0.5-1.0 m/year is consistent with the colony's current size given its estimated age. This organism illustrates the fundamentally different growth strategy of fungi compared to animals: rather than growing as a discrete, bounded body, fungal mycelia can expand indefinitely as long as resources are available. The genetic uniformity of this enormous colony has been confirmed through molecular analysis.

questions.question: To test whether mycorrhizal fungi can transfer phosphorus from a dying tree to its healthy neighbors through a common mycorrhizal network, a researcher should:
options: Add radioactive 33P-labeled phosphate to a dying tree's root zone and detect 33P accumulation in neighboring trees connected by CMN, with controls including severed CMN connections and physical barriers
Measure total phosphorus in leaves of trees near dying versus healthy trees
Observe mushroom distribution around dying trees
Compare root phosphorus concentrations in species that form ECM versus AM associations
questions.explanation: Using radioactive 33P as a tracer provides direct, quantitative evidence of phosphorus transfer through common mycorrhizal networks. The experimental design: (1) Inject 33P-labeled phosphate into the root zone of a dying tree (donor). (2) After a defined period, harvest root and leaf tissue from neighboring trees and measure 33P incorporation using scintillation counting. (3) Critical controls include: trees with CMN connections severed by trenching and root barriers (to distinguish CMN transfer from soil diffusion), trees at distances beyond CMN reach, and trees of non-mycorrhizal species. (4) Additional controls should include trees separated by mesh that allows hyphae but not roots to pass (25 μm mesh) versus mesh that blocks both (0.5 μm mesh). Detection of 33P in receiver trees connected by intact CMN but not in severed-CMN controls would provide strong evidence for network-mediated phosphorus transfer.

questions.question: Fungi obtain nutrition through absorptive heterotrophy. What specific enzymatic strategy allows saprotrophic fungi to decompose lignin, the most recalcitrant structural polymer in wood?
options: Fungi use cellulase to decompose lignin directly

White-rot basidiomycetes secrete extracellular lignin peroxidases and manganese peroxidases that generate highly reactive free radicals, which non-specifically oxidize and cleave the complex aromatic polymer of lignin—a process no other organisms perform as effectively
Fungi only decompose simple sugars, not structural polymers
Lignin decomposes spontaneously without enzymatic action
questions.explanation: Lignin decomposition by fungi is ecologically critical: (1) Lignin structure: A complex, irregular aromatic polymer of phenylpropanoid units (coniferyl, sinapyl, p-coumaryl alcohols) cross-linked by diverse C-C and C-O-C bonds. Its irregularity and hydrophobicity make it extremely resistant to enzymatic attack. (2) White-rot fungi (primarily basidiomycetes: Phanerochaete chrysosporium, Trametes versicolor): Produce lignin peroxidase (LiP), manganese peroxidase (MnP), and laccase. These enzymes generate free radicals that attack lignin non-specifically—the irregularity of lignin requires a non-specific oxidative mechanism. (3) Brown-rot fungi: Degrade cellulose but modify lignin only partially (demethylation), leaving a brown residue. (4) Evolutionary importance: The evolution of lignin peroxidases in Agaricomycetes (~290 Mya) may have ended the Carboniferous period—before these enzymes evolved, dead wood accumulated without decomposition, forming vast coal deposits. The appearance of effective lignin decomposition reduced carbon burial rates. (5) Biotechnology: Lignin-degrading enzymes are used in biofuel production, paper pulping, and bioremediation of persistent organic pollutants.
