questions.question: Genome comparisons reveal that plant-parasitic fungi have expanded gene families encoding: secreted proteases — 3x more than saprophytes; cell-wall-degrading enzymes targeting plant pectin — 5x more; small secreted proteins (effectors) — 10x more; but have reduced: genes for lignin degradation — 0.2x that of saprophytes. This pattern reflects:
options: random gene duplication with no functional significance
a sequencing error producing artifactual gene count differences
adaptive genome evolution for plant pathogenesis: expansion of genes for breaching plant defenses and suppressing immunity, with loss of saprophytic decomposition capacity
convergent evolution with animal parasites in all gene categories
questions.explanation: The genomic patterns reveal clear signatures of adaptive evolution for plant parasitism. Expansion of secreted proteases aids in degrading plant defense proteins and cell wall structural proteins. Massive expansion of pectin-degrading enzymes reflects the importance of degrading the pectin-rich middle lamella to penetrate between plant cells. The 10-fold expansion of small secreted proteins (effectors) is particularly significant—these are molecules injected into plant cells to suppress immune responses, manipulate host metabolism, and create a favorable environment for fungal growth. Conversely, the reduction in lignin-degrading enzyme genes makes biological sense: plant parasites primarily attack living tissue where lignin is less accessible than in dead wood. This trade-off between pathogenic and saprophytic capacity reflects evolutionary specialization for the parasitic niche.

questions.question: White-nose syndrome (WNS) in North American bats is caused by:
options: a bacterial infection of the respiratory tract
Pseudogymnoascus destructans, a psychrophilic (cold-loving) ascomycete fungus that infects skin during hibernation
a parasitic mite that feeds on bat wing membranes
a viral hemorrhagic disease transmitted by mosquitoes
questions.explanation: White-nose syndrome is caused by Pseudogymnoascus destructans, a psychrophilic fungus that thrives at the cold temperatures (2-14 degrees C) found in bat hibernacula (caves and mines). During hibernation, when bat immune systems are suppressed and body temperature drops to ambient, the fungus invades the skin of the muzzle, ears, and wing membranes. The characteristic white fungal growth on the nose gives the disease its name. WNS disrupts the wing membrane's physiological functions (water balance, gas exchange), causing bats to arouse from torpor more frequently, depleting fat reserves and leading to starvation, dehydration, and death. Since its detection in New York in 2006, WNS has killed an estimated 6-7 million bats in North America. The fungus is native to Europe, where bats appear resistant, suggesting North American bats lack evolved defenses against this pathogen.

questions.question: To determine whether common mycorrhizal networks (CMNs) transfer defense signals between connected plants, a researcher should:
options: Grow pairs of plants connected by mycorrhizal networks, damage one plant (donor), and measure defense gene expression in the undamaged partner (receiver), with controls including disconnected pairs and pairs sharing soil water but not mycorrhizal connections
Spray both plants simultaneously with a defense-inducing chemical
Sequence the genomes of the mycorrhizal fungus and both plant species
Measure total fungal biomass in soil between the two plants
questions.explanation: Testing whether CMNs transfer defense signals requires carefully designed controls to distinguish CMN-mediated signaling from other pathways (volatile organic compounds, root exudates in shared soil water). The experimental design should include: (1) CMN-connected pairs where only the donor is damaged—if the receiver shows defense gene upregulation, signaling has occurred. (2) Physical barriers that block hyphal connections but allow shared soil solution, to distinguish CMN transfer from chemical diffusion through soil. (3) Completely separated pairs to control for volatile signaling (which can be addressed by activated carbon filters between plants). (4) Sham-damaged controls. Measuring defense gene expression (e.g., PR proteins, jasmonic acid pathway genes) in receiver plants at multiple time points after donor damage allows detection of signal transfer timing and magnitude.

questions.question: Fungal spore dispersal mechanisms include all of the following EXCEPT:
options: active discharge of ascospores from asci using turgor pressure
wind dispersal of dry basidiospores released from gills
ballistic discharge of sporangiospores by Pilobolus using a water cannon mechanism
photosynthetic energy to propel spores through air using light-driven motors
questions.explanation: Fungi have evolved diverse and sophisticated spore dispersal mechanisms. Active ascospore discharge in Ascomycota involves building turgor pressure within the ascus until it forcibly ejects spores—some species can launch spores at initial velocities exceeding 25 m/s over distances of several centimeters. Basidiospore discharge from basidia involves the Buller's drop mechanism, where surface tension energy from a small water droplet catapults spores off the sterigma. Pilobolus (the 'hat thrower') is a zygomycete that launches its entire sporangium using hydrostatic pressure, aiming toward light (phototropism) to project sporangia onto illuminated grass blades where they will be ingested by herbivores. However, no fungus uses photosynthetic energy or light-driven motors for spore propulsion.

questions.question: The cell walls of fungi are composed primarily of:
options: chitin, a polymer of N-acetylglucosamine
cellulose, similar to plant cell walls
peptidoglycan, as found in bacterial cell walls
silica, providing structural rigidity
questions.explanation: Fungal cell walls are composed primarily of chitin, a structural polysaccharide that is a polymer of N-acetylglucosamine (GlcNAc) linked by beta-1,4 glycosidic bonds. Chitin is the same polymer found in arthropod exoskeletons, providing excellent tensile strength and chemical resistance. The fungal cell wall also contains beta-glucans (polymers of glucose), glycoproteins (particularly mannoproteins), and other polysaccharides. The cell wall provides structural support, protection against osmotic stress, and serves as the interface between the fungus and its environment. The absence of cellulose (found in plant cell walls) and peptidoglycan (found in bacterial cell walls) is one of many features distinguishing fungi from plants and bacteria.

questions.question: Coenocytic hyphae, found in zygomycetes, are characterized by:
options: lacking septa, containing many nuclei within a continuous cytoplasmic mass
having septa (cross-walls) dividing cells at regular intervals
being composed of dead, hollow cells that function in water transport
having a single nucleus per cell with thick, pigmented walls
questions.explanation: Coenocytic (or aseptate) hyphae lack internal cross-walls (septa), creating long, tubular cells containing many nuclei distributed throughout a continuous cytoplasm. This organization is characteristic of zygomycetes (such as Rhizopus and Mucor) and some other fungal lineages. The multinucleate condition results from repeated nuclear division without cytokinesis. Cytoplasmic streaming can rapidly transport nutrients, organelles, and signaling molecules throughout the coenocytic hypha. However, septa may form to seal off damaged portions or to isolate reproductive structures. In contrast, ascomycetes and basidiomycetes have septate hyphae with septa dividing the hypha into discrete cells, though these septa typically have pores allowing cytoplasmic continuity. The coenocytic organization is considered ancestral in fungi.

questions.question: The ergot fungus Claviceps purpurea infects grain crops and produces alkaloids that can cause:
options: enhanced immune function and improved digestion
ergotism, characterized by hallucinations, convulsions, and gangrene due to vasoconstriction
improved nutritional value of contaminated grain
increased grain yield through growth hormone production
questions.explanation: Claviceps purpurea is an ascomycete that infects cereal grains (particularly rye) and replaces the seed with a dark sclerotium (ergot) containing ergot alkaloids. These alkaloids are structurally similar to neurotransmitters (serotonin, dopamine, norepinephrine) and cause ergotism when consumed. Convulsive ergotism involves seizures, hallucinations, and psychosis. Gangrenous ergotism results from intense peripheral vasoconstriction that restricts blood flow to extremities, causing tissue necrosis and loss of limbs. Historically, ergot outbreaks caused epidemics of 'St. Anthony's Fire' in medieval Europe. Ergot alkaloids have also been important in medicine: ergotamine for migraine treatment, ergonovine for postpartum hemorrhage, and lysergic acid (the precursor of LSD) was first isolated from ergot alkaloids by Albert Hofmann.

questions.question: A researcher hypothesizes that decomposer fungi in forest ecosystems preferentially colonize substrates based on their carbon-to-nitrogen ratio. To test this, the researcher should:
options: Place standardized substrates with different C:N ratios in the forest and measure fungal colonization rates and community composition over time
Count the number of mushrooms visible in different parts of the forest
Analyze the chemical composition of different wood species and predict which will decompose fastest
Grow fungi in pure culture on a single type of agar medium
questions.explanation: Standardized substrate experiments (also called decomposition assays) are the gold standard for testing fungal substrate preferences. The design involves creating substrates with controlled C:N ratios (e.g., pure cellulose mixed with varying amounts of nitrogen source) and deploying them in the forest in mesh bags that allow fungal colonization but exclude macrofauna. Over time, the researcher measures: (1) mass loss (decomposition rate), (2) fungal biomass (ergosterol content or DNA quantification), and (3) fungal community composition (ITS amplicon sequencing) on each substrate. Using standardized substrates eliminates confounding variables present in natural substrates and allows direct attribution of colonization patterns to C:N ratio differences.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements about fungal reproduction:
(I) Fungi can reproduce both sexually and asexually
(II) Asexual reproduction in fungi often involves production of conidia or sporangiospores
(III) Sexual reproduction in all fungi involves a prolonged diploid phase
(IV) Mating type is determined by specific genetic loci rather than by sex chromosomes
Which are TRUE?
options: TTFT — I, II, and IV are true
TTTF — I, II, and III are true
TFTT — I, III, and IV are true
TTTT — All are true
questions.explanation: Statement I is TRUE: Most fungi can reproduce both sexually and asexually, and many spend most of their life cycle in the asexual (anamorphic) phase. Statement II is TRUE: Asexual spore production is the primary means of rapid propagation. Conidia are produced externally on conidiophores (Ascomycota, some others), while sporangiospores are produced internally within sporangia (Zygomycota). Statement III is FALSE: The diploid phase in most fungi is extremely brief. In Dikarya, cells spend extended periods in the dikaryotic (n+n) state, and the true diploid (2n) state exists only transiently in the ascus or basidium, immediately followed by meiosis. Even in other fungal groups, the diploid phase is typically short. Statement IV is TRUE: Fungal mating compatibility is determined by genetic loci (MAT loci) rather than sex chromosomes. Many fungi have two mating types, but some basidiomycetes have thousands of mating types determined by multiallelic MAT loci.

questions.question: Anaerobic fungi of the phylum Neocallimastigomycota are found in:
options: deep-sea hydrothermal vents
the digestive systems of herbivorous mammals, where they play a crucial role in fiber degradation
permanently frozen permafrost soils
the upper atmosphere at altitudes above 10 km
questions.explanation: Neocallimastigomycota are obligately anaerobic fungi found in the rumen and hindgut of herbivorous mammals (cattle, sheep, horses, elephants). They are the only known obligately anaerobic fungi and lack mitochondria, instead possessing hydrogenosomes that produce hydrogen gas as a metabolic byproduct. These fungi are exceptionally efficient at degrading plant cell wall polysaccharides (cellulose, hemicellulose) using a multi-enzyme complex called the cellulosome—a feature convergent with anaerobic bacteria. They produce rhizoidal growth that physically penetrates plant tissue, increasing the surface area available for enzymatic attack. Neocallimastigomycetes contribute significantly to fiber digestion in ruminants (estimated 5-10% of total fiber degradation) and are of biotechnological interest as sources of thermostable cellulases for biofuel production. Like chytrids, they produce flagellated zoospores.

questions.question: A mycologist discovers a novel fungal species in soil and wants to determine its phylogenetic placement. What molecular approach is standard for fungal taxonomy, and why?
options: Sequence the entire genome and compare all genes simultaneously
Measure hyphal diameter under a microscope

Sequence the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region of ribosomal DNA, which is the universal barcode for fungi—ITS provides sufficient variation to distinguish most species while being conserved enough for PCR amplification across all fungal lineages, and an extensive reference database exists for comparison
Analyze cell wall biochemistry exclusively
questions.explanation: ITS is the standard fungal barcode: (1) ITS region: Located between the 18S, 5.8S, and 28S ribosomal RNA genes. ITS1 (between 18S and 5.8S) and ITS2 (between 5.8S and 28S) are non-coding spacers that evolve rapidly enough to distinguish closely related species. (2) Why ITS works for fungi: Universal primers (ITS1/ITS4, ITS1F/ITS4) amplify across all fungal lineages. The multicopy nature of rDNA allows amplification from small or degraded samples. ITS variation is sufficient for species-level discrimination in most groups. (3) UNITE database: The largest curated ITS reference database, containing >1 million sequences with species hypotheses (SHs) based on sequence clustering. (4) Limitations: ITS resolution is insufficient for some groups (Fusarium, Penicillium, Aspergillus) where additional loci are needed (TEF1-alpha, RPB1, RPB2, beta-tubulin). (5) For higher-level phylogenetics: Multi-locus analyses using LSU (28S), SSU (18S), and protein-coding genes provide backbone phylogenies. Phylogenomics using hundreds of conserved orthologs is increasingly used for deep fungal relationships.

questions.question: Chytrids (Chytridiomycota) are unique among fungi in possessing:
options: flagellated zoospores capable of swimming through water
multicellular fruiting bodies with complex tissue organization
the ability to photosynthesize using chloroplasts
cell walls made of cellulose instead of chitin
questions.explanation: Chytridiomycota are the only major fungal group that retains flagellated cells. Their zoospores (and in some species, gametes) each possess a single posterior whiplash flagellum—the ancestral condition for the Opisthokonta. This flagellum enables active swimming through water, reflecting the aquatic origin of fungi. Most other fungal lineages have lost flagella entirely, an adaptation to terrestrial existence where spore dispersal occurs through air currents, animal vectors, or water splashing. Chytrids are predominantly aquatic or soil-dwelling organisms, often parasitizing algae, other fungi, plant pollen, or amphibians. The chytrid Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis has devastated amphibian populations worldwide, causing the disease chytridiomycosis. Molecular phylogenetics places chytrids as an early-diverging fungal lineage, consistent with the ancestral nature of their flagellated zoospores.

questions.question: Horizontal gene transfer from fungi to insects has been documented, including:
options: transfer of carotenoid biosynthesis genes to aphids, enabling aphids to produce red and green pigments without dietary carotenoid intake
transfer of cellulose synthesis genes enabling insect cell wall production
transfer of chitin synthesis genes from fungi to all arthropods
transfer of photosynthesis genes from lichens to butterfly wings
questions.explanation: One of the most striking documented cases of horizontal gene transfer (HGT) between fungi and animals involves carotenoid biosynthesis genes transferred from fungi to pea aphids (Acyrthosiphon pisum). Aphids are the only known animals that can synthesize carotenoid pigments de novo, using genes of clear fungal origin integrated into their genome. These genes encode carotenoid desaturase and carotenoid cyclase/synthase enzymes. Different allelic variants of the carotenoid desaturase gene determine whether aphids produce red or green pigmentation—a trait with ecological significance as color morphs differ in predation vulnerability and parasitoid susceptibility. Phylogenetic analysis confirms these genes cluster with fungal, not animal, sequences, and they are flanked by insect transposable elements suggesting the mechanism of integration. This represents one of the most well-documented cases of functional HGT between kingdoms.

questions.question: The parasitic fungus Cordyceps militaris, used in traditional medicine, infects and kills insect larvae. After host death, the fungus produces a distinctive:
options: Underground truffle-like fruiting body
Bright orange club-shaped stroma (fruiting body) that erupts from the insect cadaver
Invisible layer of spores on the insect's surface
Liquid exudate that attracts other insects for secondary infection
questions.explanation: Cordyceps militaris produces a distinctive bright orange, club-shaped stroma (fruiting body) that erupts from the body of its dead insect host. The stroma can reach several centimeters in length and produces perithecia containing asci and ascospores on its surface. The brightly colored stroma serves as a sporulation platform, releasing ascospores into the air to infect new insect hosts. Cordyceps militaris has been valued in traditional Chinese medicine for centuries (often as a substitute for the rarer C. sinensis) and produces the bioactive compound cordycepin (3-deoxyadenosine), which has demonstrated anti-tumor, anti-inflammatory, and immunomodulatory properties in laboratory studies. The genus Cordyceps and related genera (Ophiocordyceps, Metacordyceps) include hundreds of species that parasitize diverse arthropod hosts, representing one of the most species-rich groups of entomopathogenic fungi.

questions.question: A study compares carbon allocation in ectomycorrhizal symbiosis: Plant carbon invested in ECM fungi — 15-25% of total photosynthate; Phosphorus uptake enhancement — 300-500% increase; Nitrogen uptake enhancement — 200-300% increase; Drought survival improvement — 40-60% increase. The cost-benefit analysis suggests:
options: The plant loses more than it gains from the mycorrhizal association
The significant carbon cost (15-25%) is offset by much larger gains in mineral nutrition and stress tolerance, representing a net fitness benefit
The fungus parasitizes the plant but provides no measurable benefits
Carbon investment in mycorrhizae reduces plant growth in all conditions
questions.explanation: The data presents a clear cost-benefit picture of ectomycorrhizal symbiosis. The plant invests 15-25% of its photosynthate—a substantial carbon cost—to maintain the fungal partner. In return, phosphorus uptake increases 300-500% and nitrogen uptake increases 200-300%, along with a 40-60% improvement in drought survival. In nutrient-poor soils (where most ECM plants grow), the return on investment is highly favorable: a 25% carbon cost to achieve a 300-500% increase in the most limiting nutrient (phosphorus) represents an excellent trade. The enhanced drought tolerance provides additional insurance value. This explains why the mycorrhizal symbiosis has been maintained for over 400 million years of evolution. However, the net benefit is context-dependent—in nutrient-rich soils, the carbon cost may exceed the nutritional benefit.
